data.title: Alan Arkin no more: Life and Times of The Kominsky Method and Little Miss Sunshine actor
data.meta_description: Oscar Award-winning actor Alan Arkin, famous for Little Miss Sunshine and The Kominsky Method, has died at 89. Here are some things to know about him.
data.text:
Synopsis

Oscar Award-winning actor Alan Arkin, famous for Little Miss Sunshine and The Kominsky Method, has died at 89. Here are some things to know about him.

Oscar Award-winning actor Alan Arkin passed away on June 29, 2023. He was 89. His representative Melody Korenbrot shared the news of his death with USA TODAY. The actor’s sons Adam, Matthew, and Anthony jointly shared a statement to People Magazine.

#Budget' 2024 with ET

Union Budget and Economic Survey 2024 Live Updates

Economic Survey Highlights: Reading between the lines

The statement read: "Our father was a uniquely talented force of nature, both as an artist and a man. A loving husband, father, grand grandfather, he was adored and will be deeply missed."

Alan Arkin was recently seen in the first two seasons of Netflix’s The Kominsky Method, an award-winning series in which he played Norman, the agent of Michael Douglas' character of acting coach Sandy.

About Alan Arkin

Alan Arkin was born on March 26, 1934, in Brooklyn, New York, United States, in a Jewish family. His father was a writer and painter, and his mother was a teacher.

Alan Arkin’s Oscar Awards

Alan Arkin won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for Little Miss Sunshine (2006 film) and was nominated four times, including two Best Actor nominations for The Russians Are Coming (1966 film) and The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter (1968 film), and a Best Supporting Actor nod for Argo (2012).

However, he did not think highly of the Oscars. "I think it's all nonsense," Arkin had told USA TODAY before the Oscars 2013. "The whole thing’s a cr*pshoot. If I look at the movies that won best movie over the last 50 years, 20 are ridiculous jokes," he opined.

Not many know that Alan Arkin's directorial debut was the Oscar-nominated short children's film, People Soup, in 1969. The 12-minute film starred his sons Adam Arkin and Matthew Arkin as boys who create a magical soup with kitchen ingredients, which transforms them into animals or objects. People, Soup was based on Alan Arkin’s own story that was published in Galaxy Science Fiction in 1958.

Alan Arkin despised the box office race in Hollywood. "For the industry to treat us like horses, who’s in first or second, is insanity," he said at a Screen Actors Guild Foundation event in 2012.

In his early 20s, Arkin was a member of the folk group The Tarriers, whose The Banana Boat Song was a hit. After working in New York theater, he joined Second City, the now legendary improvisational group in Chicago. Second City performed in New York, and Arkin got noticed in Los Angeles and never looked back.

Alan Arkin is survived by three sons from his first two marriages – aforementioned Anthony, Matthew, and Adam Arkin, who are actors – and his third wife, Suzanne Newlander, who is a psychotherapist.

FAQs

Q1:How did Alan Arkin die?

Oscar-winning actor Alan Arkin died on June 29, 2023, of heart ailments. He was 89 years old.

Q2:What are Alan Arkin’s films?

Some of Alan Arkin’s films include The Russians Are Coming, Catch-22, The Seven-Per-Cent Solution, Edward Scissorhands, Glengarry Glen Ross, Grosse Pointe Blank, Little Miss Sunshine, and The Kominsky Method web series.
